title.rendered: Have you experienced cyber bullying?  Identify its modalities and protect yourself!  |  National Commission to Prevent and Eradicate Violence Against Women |  Government

content.rendered:
In Mexico, according to the National Institute of Statistics and Geography, in 2005an 35.82% of minors primary and secondary have been involved directly in online social violencebeing the most common way the cell phonefollowed by the internet and cell phone or computer cameras.

In this new digital era in which online contact has diluted the spatial boundaries between people, cyber bullying too a increased their presence andn the extent that we have contact with digital media of communication, which also increases our exposure to online violence. Therefore, it is important to know what cyberbullying is.

The cyber bullying is a aggressive and intentional act carried out repeatedly and constant over time, through the use of electronic contact forms by a group or individual against a victim who cannot easily defend himself.

Photo by Cristina Rodriguez.

“Women, who represent almost half of Mexican Internet users, are harassed by strangers, while their partners pretend to have control of their accounts on social networks and monitor the messages they receive or send.”

The most common forms of cyber bullying according to the book “Cyber ​​bullying: Bullying in the digital age” by Robin M. Kowalski, occur in instant messaging, email, text messages through cell phones, social networks , chats, blogs and internet games. Kowalski identifies at least 8 types of cyber bullying:

  1. electronic insultsoffenses that one or some user makes to another or another.

  2. Harassmentinvolves repeatedly sending offensive messages to a specific person, whether through email, chats, text messages, etc.

  3. denigrationrefers to the dissemination of derogatory or false information about a person, as is the case with the publication of altered photographs.

  4. Impersonationimplies that the harasser pretends to be the victim, either using the access password of their online accounts to send aggressive or offensive messages or third parties as if they had been sent by the victim.

  5. Elicitationlies in disclosing private information of the victim that was initially sent by the victim privately or elicited and then disseminated to other people without the victim’s permission.

  6. Exclusionis done with the purpose of excluding her or not letting her participate.

  7. cyber stalkingconsists of sending repeated harassing and threatening electronic communications.

  8. happy slappingin which a physical aggression is carried out that is recorded by some digital means to be published on the network and be public.

These acts generate fear, confusion and insecurity in the victims, even reaching the point of not allowing them to feel safe anywhere for fear of being recognized and, therefore, harassed.

Photo: Learn Bolivia.

It is important to reflect that cyber bullying is also violencesince the victims severely affects development of their personality, and to the people they harass, it makes them believe that they enjoy impunity in the face of these acts.

Therefore, it is important that those who have been victims of cyberbullying, both men and women, speak up and report this situation and lose their fear of the use of new communication and information technologies.

If you want to report cyber violence you can go to:

Cyber ​​Police of the National Security Commission: to the telephone number 088, which operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. You can also make complaints through the Twitter account @CEAC_CNS, the email ceac@cns.gob.mx, and the PF Móvil application, available for all cell phone platforms.

Cyber ​​Police in Mexico City: policia.cibernetica@ssp.df.gob.mx @UCS_CDMX #CiberneticaCDMX

Furthermore, it is important to know that There are complaint mechanisms that social networks have. We leave you some tutorials and links that can guide you to denounce or report aggressions and acts of cyberbullying in the following social networks:

  1. Twitter.

  2. Facebook.

  3. Youtube.
